Literature Review: Sequential Monte Carlo (SMC) methods, commonly referred to as particle filters, have emerged as a powerful tool for addressing filtering problems in nonlinear state-space systems. These methods are particularly valuable in scenarios where traditional analytical solutions are intractable due to the complexity of the systems involved. The core principle of SMC methods is the use of Monte Carlo integration to approximate the posterior distributions of interest, thereby facilitating state estimation and system identification in complex environments. This literature review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the foundational concepts, algorithmic variations, and application domains of SMC methods, drawing on a selection of key studies in the field. The inception of SMC methods can be traced back to the need for efficient algorithms capable of handling the challenges posed by nonlinear and non-Gaussian state-space models. Early work by Gordon, Salmond, and Smith (1993) introduced the bootstrap particle filter, which laid the groundwork for subsequent developments in the field. This algorithm employs a sequential importance sampling (SIS) approach, combined with a resampling step to mitigate the problem of particle degeneracy. The bootstrap particle filter demonstrated the potential of SMC methods for practical applications, particularly in tracking and navigation systems. Building on this foundation, Doucet, Godsill, and Andrieu (2000) provided a comprehensive theoretical framework for SMC methods, elucidating the conditions under which these algorithms converge to the true posterior distribution. Their work highlighted the importance of designing effective proposal distributions and resampling strategies to enhance the performance of particle filters. This theoretical insight paved the way for the development of more sophisticated SMC algorithms, such as the auxiliary particle filter and the Rao-Blackwellized particle filter, which offer improved efficiency and accuracy in specific contexts. The auxiliary particle filter, introduced by Pitt and Shephard (1999), addresses the issue of sample impoverishment by incorporating information about the future state into the proposal distribution. This approach has been shown to yield significant improvements in estimation accuracy, particularly in systems with high-dimensional state spaces. Similarly, the Rao-Blackwellized particle filter, proposed by Doucet, de Freitas, and Gordon (2000), leverages the structure of the state-space model to reduce the variance of the estimates, thereby enhancing the overall performance of the filter. In addition to these algorithmic advancements, researchers have explored various extensions and applications of SMC methods. For instance, Andrieu, Doucet, and Holenstein (2010) introduced particle Markov chain Monte Carlo (PMCMC) methods, which combine the strengths of SMC and MCMC techniques to tackle more complex inference problems. This hybrid approach has been successfully applied in areas such as Bayesian parameter estimation and model comparison, demonstrating the versatility of SMC methods. The application domains of SMC methods are vast and varied, encompassing fields such as robotics, finance, and bioinformatics. In robotics, particle filters have been widely used for simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM), enabling autonomous vehicles to navigate unknown environments with high precision. In finance, SMC methods have been employed for the estimation of stochastic volatility models, providing valuable insights into market dynamics. In bioinformatics, particle filters have been applied to the analysis of gene regulatory networks, facilitating the identification of key regulatory mechanisms. Despite their numerous advantages, SMC methods are not without limitations. One of the primary challenges is the computational cost associated with maintaining a large number of particles, particularly in high-dimensional systems. To address this issue, researchers have developed various strategies for reducing the computational burden, such as adaptive resampling and parallelization techniques. Additionally, the design of effective proposal distributions remains a critical area of research, as it directly impacts the efficiency and accuracy of the particle filter. In conclusion, SMC methods have proven to be a versatile and powerful tool for addressing filtering problems in nonlinear state-space systems. Through a combination of theoretical insights and algorithmic innovations, researchers have significantly advanced the state of the art in this field, enabling the application of particle filters to a wide range of complex problems. As the demand for efficient and accurate state estimation techniques continues to grow, it is likely that SMC methods will remain at the forefront of research in this area, driving further advancements and applications in the years to come.
